content.description: The obvious roof above the road across from the Snow Creek parking lot.  Apparently this route is now free few details are known at this time.  As Jonah notes below, nailing is not acceptable on this route.

Long ignored, but deserving more attention. The chimney can be climbed mostly as a straight in crack. The crux is some steep face climbing getting into the chimney.

When I was on this some very large rocks peeled off near the start. It is cleaner now, but requires some thin insecure face moves that are very hard to protect. There is a shallow cam placement on the left side but the rock is soft there. I was considering adding a bolt. If you climb this let me know if you think it is needed.
content.protection: standard rack to 2". bolted anchor is for the Visor about 15' to the left, you can place a cam in a crack above the big ledge for a directional to bring up the 2nd. No chains , bring sling or walk off, or access routes above.
content.location: right side of the Visor, about 50' west of the snow closure gate near Snow Creek parking lot.

content.description: I hope I am not sand-bagging a 5.7 leader, but this is one that is listed in the guide as 5.8, and is quite a bit easier than other Leavenworth 5.8's
content.protection: gear to 2", but you could use a #3 too. Bolted anchor.
content.location:
on the left side of the Visor, with the 5.13 roof.

Directly off the road, about 100' up road from the Snow gate.

content.description: Short, obscure, awkward and well worth doing. Hand crack, juggy face holds= fun.
content.protection: gear to 2". I think  the anchor was bolts, no chain.
content.location:
First little wall you come to on the left of Rainbow falls. Leftward traverse up grassy benches.

You will pass an even smaller wall with a steep splitter finger crack that was considered a 5.12 top rope.

There is a fir tree at the top, a cave at the base, RFC on left is 5.11 thin fingers, there is another short face climb to the right. Walk off the top left and down climb gully with trees or further left.

content.description: Climb the wide crack to the top!
content.location: The obvious wide crack in between La Bamba and Twelve Bees

content.description: This gets 1 star in Kramar's book, I think he prefers slabs. This is a great and fun little climb. Seems soft for the Leavenworth grade of 10d. Maybe 10c or 10b. The book also says gear to 1". the first piece is a #3, and you could place a #2 or #3 up higher on the right side of flake.
content.protection: mostly medium size cams .4- #3. Good cord on tree( 8/2014) could walk off to SW.
content.location: follow trail towards waterfall, veer left from waterfall, pass a short double finger crack with big flat area, continue uphill, this is on the left, bolted 5.12 to right, Madsen's chimney ( actually an OW) further right.

content.description: A fun sport route on solid rock with a couple cruxes, Kramar's guide talks about a crux at the first bolt but I found the top to be much more difficult, possibly because of the new anchor up and left.  Drifting towards the chimney substantially reduces the grade.

Killer line with 2 cruxes. You can build an anchor in the corner at the base of the crack to hold the belayer in place on a decent ledge. Fire up and back on powerful hand jams and pull onto the decent ledge around the corner. Rest up and get ready to fire the roof on solid but painful finger locks. After the roof the climbing eases off to around 10a, but is a little dirty.
content.protection: Doubles from fingers to #1, a single #2 should sort it out. The upper crack ranges from thin hands to fingers.
content.location:
North side of the Icicle, 400 feet above the road, just past the Snow Creek Wall parking lot. You should be able to see the crazy roof from the road. It is just below Madsen's Buttress. There is a faint trail on the right side of the seasonal drainage that winds its way up the hillside to the roof.

The prominent line up the center of the air roof starting in the back corner of the alcove.
